utterances: Mm-hmm.

...especially interested to read through the records of the New York 69th as they marched down the hill and what happened to them as they approached the Confederates at the Battle of Antietam and were...
Oh, yes.
...utterly slaughtered.
Oh, yes.
And it is a moving experience to realize that your relatives and some of the people they knew were part of that battle.
And that's the connection.
I - when I talk, inevitably, I'm going to hear from somebody in the audience whose great-great-grandfather was there.
Andy Trudeau, thanks very much for your time today.
Appreciate it.
Noah Andy - Andre - Noah Andre Trudeau.
His most recent book is ""Robert E.
Lee: Lessons in Leadership,"" and he was kind enough to join us here in Studio 3A.
From NPR News, it's DAY TO DAY.
The House of Representatives takes on the massive 2007 farm bill today.
There's a lot of money at stake for a lot of people, everyone from farmers to those on food stamps.
Here to tell us about the legislation is John Dimsdale from MARKETPLACE.
John, this is a massive, massive bill, but can you remind us of some of the highlights?
Sure.
Every five years the farm bill is the occasion for reformers to try to wean farmers from government subsidies.
The farm bill establishes government guarantees for minimum prices for crops to try to shield growers from some of the many risks that they take.
There are always stories though about wealthy farmers getting even richer, thanks to taxpayers.
So the divisions in the farm bill aren't usually between Democrats and Republicans.
It pits farm state against urban lawmakers.
And the city slickers are always trying to reduce support payments.
This year, those reformers had been anticipating help from the new Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi.
She represents a very urban district in San Francisco, but she surprised a lot of people and sided more with the farm interests in this bill.
Now, she insists that this bill does cut subsidies and would eliminate government benefits for farmers with an adjusted income of a million dollars or more.
But critics say it's easy for a wealthy farmer to find deductible expenses to bring their adjusted income under a million, so there aren't really any subsidy cuts here.
It's been reported that the White House has threatened a veto.
What are the administration's concerns here?
Yeah, well, to pay for a hefty increase in food stamp benefits, Democrats have added a tax that applies to foreign companies with U.S.
subsidiaries.
The Democrats say they're merely closing loopholes that allow these companies to send their profits overseas and evade U.S.
taxes.
But businesses, joined by most of the Republicans and the White House, say that this is nothing more than a big tax increase.
Corporate lobbyists say the tax would violate trade treaties, chase foreign investment away from the U.S.
The Republicans say it's scuttled all the bipartisan cooperation that should have made this bill easy to pass, and the momentum for it has slowed.
Although Democrats insist that they still have the votes to pass it.
And what about those farm support payments?
What might happened to them?
Well, the House is going to take up an amendment that would cut direct payments to farmers by 40 percent.
Direct payments were begun about 10 years ago.
They were supposed to be a one-time deal to wean farmers from crop subsidies and price supports.
But they were extended in the 2002 farm bill and they're back this year.
A group of moderate Democrats and Republicans want to cut them back substantially, say, $10 billion over 10 years.
They're proposing to spend at least some of that on land conservation and wetland preservation.
That's popular.
So this vote will be interesting.
Thank you so much, John.
John Dimsdale of Public Radio's daily business show MARKETPLACE.
It's produced by American Public Media.
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
Im Rebecca Roberts in Washington.
Neal Conan is away.
So for me, no. I didn't they just did not work at all.
I found them...
So what did you do with that yawning hole?
I'll accept this as a very common thing.
And I'll accept that I've heard from any number of illustrious professors - or broadcasters, for that matter - the fear, I'll be found out.
But I mean, Sir Paul McCartney - I mean, you have had success in so many dimensions of music.
You really feel a competitive insecurity with somebody else who's coming out with a record?
Unfortunately, yes.
I think one thing that's good about it is, I think it's a good motivator.
I think it keeps you hungry.
I think the minute you're full up and have had enough to eat, then that's time to retire.
But I agree with you.
You know, I should be able to look at my accolades and go: Come on, Paul, that's enough.
But there's still this little voice in the back of my brain, goes: No, no, no, you could do better.
This person over here is excelling.
Try harder.
It still can be a little bit intimidating.
You know?
Well, Paul McCartney, it's been an honor to help build up your ego here in this session...
(LAUGHTER)
You've done it well.
...on ALL THINGS CONSIDERED, and helped restore some self-confidence to you.
(LAUGHTER)
And we greatly appreciate your coming in.
Well, I certainly, very much appreciate you building me up.
I was not sure.
Now, I'm certain.
(LAUGHTER)
Paul McCartney - Sir Paul McCartney, I should say, whose new album is called ""New."" Thanks a lot.
Thank you.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""QUEENIE EYE"")
It's WEEKENDS on ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.
I'm Jacki Lyden.
South Florida has been irresistible for crime writers - Carl Hiaasen, Edna Buchanan, Harry Crews are just a few who come to mind.
But novelist John Dufresne hadn't really tried his hand at the noire genre before.
Now, he brings all his gifts for humor and pathos to Eden, Florida, the imaginary setting for the family slaughter that begins Dufresne's new novel, ""No Regrets, Coyote.
It's a gripping read and off-kilter.
He hails from Massachusetts, originally, but Florida has gotten under his skin since a long time back.
John Dufresne joins me from member station WLRN in Miami.
Welcome.
Thank you, Jacki.
Great to be here.
It's difficult to call a murder mystery fun, but ""No Regrets, Coyote"" is a fun murder mystery.
And yet, it starts with this really brutal, bloody crime.
The entire Halliday family is killed in their home in South Florida, and an unlikely character is called in to help solve the crime.
He's our protagonist, our hero.
His name's Wiley Melville - nice writer's detective-type name - and goes by Coyote.
Tell us more about him.
He's not actually a detective.
No, he's not.
He's a therapist by trade, and he's called in occasionally because he has what a psychologist calls robust mirror neurons.
He's able to sort of look at people and look at their furniture and look at the way they behave themselves.
And so to determine, sass out what it is going and what people's motivations are.

One of the great fun things in this that's sort of a send-up of the whole genre is that he often has to break off from solving the crime to, you know, basically give someone a therapy session because he's so caring.
Yeah, he - he's got - he's carrying on with his business.
It's like, this is - we all have our own lives that whatever trouble is going on in our life, we still have to live it.
He has to go to work every day, and he has, you know, some - these clients that have various degrees of, you know, difficulty that he's trying to work with.
And he's also got some problems in his own family with his father is suffering from dementia.
And he has to take care of his father, and his sister's kind of a hysteric.
And he's got all - he's trying to juggle all these things together at the same time while also losing his girlfriend and maybe finding another one.
In all of this, life goes on for him.
So the Halliday family, sadly, is no more - mom, pop and three kids - and the cops insist that it's murder-suicide.
But Wiley, he just isn't so sure.
Something doesn't seem right.
This suicide note's pretty badly typed - and that's interesting, it's typed - it's found next to the father.
Maybe you would give us a bit of that, please.
Yeah, OK.
So he's given the suicide note that the police have found.
He's handed it, too, and it reads like this: To whom it may concern.
To start off about this tragic story, my name is Chafin Halliday, my wife Krysia, my boys Brantley, 9, Briely, 8, and my daughter and my precious angel, Brianna, 4.
People have put obstacles in my way and know who they are.
I'm not insane.
But this is no way to live like this.
I have let my loved ones down.
I have failed at fathership.
I had to die.
I deserved it.
But to love them like I do and to live without them is too hard to bear, which is why we are dead and why we are together on the other side.
I could not leave my babies with strangers.
Yours truly, Chafin R.
Halliday.
Right away, Wylie suspects that there's just something off about all of this.
So Coyote's going to set off on this mission to find out what actually happened to this family.
He's got a sidekick - and all the detectives need one.
This is a poker player and magician type called Bay Lettique.
Tell us about Bay.
Well, Bay is a professional poker player who used to run an illegal poker game and would call Wylie in to see if anyone was cheating.
He could notice who it was, and it usually was and it was usually cops.
And they'd have to pay off the police benevolent association so no one would get in trouble.
And Bay was also like his real estate attorney at one time and all that, and so now they are best buddies.
And Wylie worries about Bay, in fact, that he can't keep himself away from the poker table.
But Bay is successful at it and makes his living that way.
